sec.title: Sensitivity and CC signals as a function of K
sec.p: We are now better armed to understand how sensitivity and CC indicators vary as a function of the readout ensemble ùìî. We are mostly interested in averages of these quantities over very large numbers of randomly chosen ensembles ùìî of size K; we thus use the generic notation E[x‚à£K]‚âîE[x(ùìî)‚à£Card(ùìî) = K] to denote the expected value of a variable x when averaging over ensembles of size K. Note that this notation is equivalent to the more explicit notation used in the main text, so that E[x‚à£K] = ‚ü®x‚ü©ùìî(K). From eq. 72 we find: E [ Y ‚à£ K ] = œÉ s 2 Œ∑ ‚ä§ E [ P ‚à£ K ] Œ∑.

To understand the properties of the (M √ó M) matrix E[P‚à£K], we view the (M √ó K) design matrix X(ùìî) (eq. 71) as a collection of K random vectors xi in mode space, viewing neuron identities i as the random variable. Thus, P(ùìî) is the orthogonal projector on the linear span of the K sample vectors {xi}i ‚àà ùìî. As a projector, its trace is equal to its rank, so we have Tr ( E [ P ‚à£ K ] ) = K. Furthermore, since K+1 samples span on average more space than K samples, we are ensured that E[P‚à£K+1] ‚âΩ E[P‚à£K], in the sense of positive semidefinite matrices.

Finally, intuition and numerical simulations suggest that E[P‚à£K] is almost diagonal. Indeed, as the various modes are linearly independent, there is no linear interplay between the different dimensions of xi across samples i. More precisely, the expectation value over neurons is ‚ü®x i m x i n ‚ü© i = N tot ‚àí 1 Œª m 2 Œ¥ m n. This leads to the matrix expression: E [ X X ‚ä§ | K ] = K N tot ‚àí 1 Œõ 2 . Let us consider the (compact) SVD decomposition X X‚ä§‚âî W D W‚ä§, with W‚ä§ W = Id, and D an invertible diagonal matrix. Then, the projection matrix P is simply equal to W W‚ä§. As for the previous equation, it rewrites E [ W D W ‚ä§ | K ] = K N tot ‚àí 1 Œõ 2 . Here, both matrices D and Œõ are diagonal. So, if we assume a form of independence between W and D, it is reasonable to suppose that E[W W‚ä§‚à£K] = E[P‚à£K] is close to diagonal as well. (Actually, we postulate that E[P‚à£K] is exactly diagonal when the random vectors xi follow a normal distribution. In the general case, small or moderate deviations from diagonality can be observed.) We denote these diagonal terms as œµ ( K ) ‚âî diag ( E [ P | K ] ) . (81) The properties of E[P‚à£K] stated above imply that ‚àëm œµm(K) = K (trace property), and œµm(K+1) ‚â• œµm(K) (growth property). Finally, we can consider the resulting approximations of sensitivity (eq. 72) and CC indicator (eq. 79): E [ Y | K ] ‚âÉ œÉ s 2 ‚àë m = 1 M œµ m ( K ) Œ∑ m 2 , (82) E [ Y Q | K ] ‚âÉ N tot ‚àí 1 œÉ s 2 ‚àë m = 1 M œµ m ( K ) Œª m 2 Œ∑ m 2 . (83) In this expression, we recognize the individual mode sensitivities y m = œÉ s 2 Œ∑ m 2. For CC signals, we also make the approximation E[YQ‚à£K] ‚âÉ E[Y‚à£K]E[Q‚à£K], and recover eq. 21‚Äì22 from the main text. Unfortunately, there is no such simple approximation for indicator V, that would lead from eq. 80 to E[V‚à£K].

sec.title: Validation on a simulated neural network
sec.p: In this final part of the Methods, we provide additional information for applying our inference method (Case 2) to experimental data. The neural network used to test our methods is described in detail in supporting S1 Text (section 3). Briefly, on each trial, 2000 input Poisson neurons fire with rate s, taking one of three possible values 25, 30 and 35 Hz (so in our simulation, stimulus units are Hz). The encoding population per se consists of 5000 leaky integrate-and-fire (LIF) neurons. 1000 of these neurons receive sparse excitatory projections from the input Poisson neurons, which naturally endows them with a positive tuning to stimulus s. Another 1000 neurons receive sparse inhibitory projections from the Poisson neurons, which naturally endows them with negative tuning. The remaining 3000 neurons receive no direct projections from the input. Instead, all neurons in the encoding population are coupled through a sparse connectivity with random delays up to 5 msec. Synaptic weights are random and balanced, leading to a mean firing rate of 21.8 Hz in the population. We implemented and simulated the network using Brian, a spiking neural network simulator in Python [39].

The ‚Äútrue‚Äù perceptual readout from this network was built from a fixed random set of K‚ãÜ = 80 neurons, with temporal parameters w‚ãÜ = 50 msec and t R ‚ãÜ = 100 msec, and decision noise œÉ d ‚ãÜ = 1 stimulus units (Hz). The readout vector a‚ãÜ was built optimally given these constraints (eq. 12). The trials used to learn a‚ãÜ were not used in the subsequent analysis. The resulting JND for the ‚Äúanimal‚Äù was Z‚ãÜ ‚âà 3 stimulus units (Hz).

Then, ‚Äúexperimentally‚Äù, neural activity was observed through 15 pools of 170 simultaneously recorded neurons, each pool being recorded on 3 √ó 180 trials. For the statistical inference method, we assumed a square integration kernel h. We tested all combinations of the following readout parameters (in matrix notation): K = 10:10:150 neurons, w = 10:10:100 msec, tR = 10:10:200 msec, œÉd = 0:0.25:3 stimulus units (Hz). For each tested size K, we picked 2000 random candidate ensembles ùìî (always within one of the 15 simultaneous pools) to build the predictions. For each ensemble ùìî, another ensemble ‚Ñê of 20 neurons, segregated from ùìî, were used to predict CC signals outside the readout ensemble (this was always possible since recording pools had size 170, and K ‚â§ 150). The details of these predictions are explained in the following paragraph. Finally, the three terms in the ‚Äústatistical‚Äù loss function (eq. 16) were weighted according to the power of the respective, true measures. That is: Œª = Z ‚ãÜ 4 ‚à´ ‚à´ d t d u q ‚ãÜ ( u , t ) 2 and Œº = Z ‚ãÜ 4 V ‚ãÜ 2 .

sec.title: Experimental predictions for CC indicators
sec.p: Here, we detail how to compute the CC indicators q(u, t) and V (eq. 14‚Äì15) from actual data. For the measured versions q‚ãÜ(u, t) and V‚ãÜ(w, tR), this is straightforward. One considers the true, measured CC signals d i ‚ãÜ ( t ), and computes the population averages in eq. 14‚Äì15 over as many neurons i as were recorded. Note however that the final indicators can be corrupted by noise, whenever each measure d i ‚ãÜ ( t ) comes from too few recording trials (this problem is addressed in the next section). Also note that, since the definition of V requires a temporal integration, we actually have to produce a different ‚Äútrue‚Äù V‚ãÜ for each tested set of temporal parameters w and tR.

Conversely, special care must be taken when it comes to predicted CC indicators. Whenever a candidate ensemble ùìî is proposed as the source of the readout, eq. 59 predicts the resulting CC signal di(t‚à£ùìî) for every neuron i in the population. However, in practice, the noise covariance term C ‚Äæ i r ( t ) is required in the computation, so neuron i and ensemble ùìî must have been recorded simultaneously during the same run. This limits the number of neurons i which can participate in the population averages.

Furthermore, choice covariances will generally differ between neurons that are part of the readout ensemble and neurons that are not (see eq. 61 and the associated discussion). As a result, the two following averages must be predicted separately: q ùìî ( u , t | ùìî ) ‚âî ‚ü® b i ( u ) d i ( t | ùìî ) ‚ü© i ‚àà ùìî , (84) q out ( u , t | ùìî ) ‚âî ‚ü® b i ( u ) d i ( t | ùìî ) ‚ü© i ‚àâ ùìî , (85) before one can recombine them in the correct proportions: p ( ùìî ) ‚âî K N tot , (86) q ( u , t | ùìî ) = p ( ùìî ) q ùìî ( u , t | ùìî ) + 1 ‚àí p ( ùìî ) q out ( u , t | ùìî ) , (87) and similarly for V(ùìî). To compute q out experimentally, each tested candidate ensemble ùìî (of size K) is associated to a complimentary set of neurons ‚Ñê (of size I), which we use to approximate the average in eq. 85: q ùìò ( u , t | ùìî ) ‚âî ‚ü® b i ( u ) d i ( t | ùìî ) ‚ü© i ‚àà ùìò . (88) All neurons in ensembles ùìî and ‚Ñê must have been recorded during the same run, which imposes that I+K ‚â§ N. Hence in our simulations, we chose a size I = 170‚àí150 = 20 neurons.

Clearly, 20 neurons is not sufficient for q‚Ñê to be a reliable population average. So in practice, we cannot estimate reliably each prediction q(u, t ‚à£ùìî) from eq. 87. Luckily, we are not interested in their value for each individual readout ensemble ùìî. We simply need to estimate their means across all tested ensembles ùìî of similar size: ‚ü® q ( u , t ) ‚ü© ùìî ‚âî q ( u , t | ùìî ) ùìî with Card ( ùìî ) = K (89) ‚ü® V ‚ü© ùìî ‚âî V ( ùìî ) ùìî with Card ( ùìî ) = K (90) which will be reliable as soon as we test a sufficient amount of candidate ensembles ùìî.

Note that in the final inference (eq. 16), a match is sought between the true indicators q‚ãÜ and V‚ãÜ‚Äîwhich arise from a single readout ensemble ùìî‚ãÜ, and the predictions ‚ü® q ‚ü© ùìî and ‚ü® V ‚ü© ùìî ‚Äîwhich are average values across all readout ensembles ùìî of size K. Thus, a prediction error can occur whenever the true readout ensemble ùìî‚ãÜ is not a ‚Äútypical‚Äù representative of its size K‚ãÜ. To quantify these potential errors, one should also estimate the indicators‚Äô variance across ensembles ùìî of same size.

sec.title: Correcting for the finite amounts of data
sec.p: The computations of Z, q and V, as described above, can produce imprecise results when the data are overly limited. Generically, for any quantity X estimated from the data, we can write X noisy = X ideal + Œæ , where Œæ represents the measurement error on X due to the finite amounts of data. If we could recompute X from a different set of neurons and/or a different set of trials, variable Œæ would take a different value‚Äîmeaning that Var(Œæ) > 0. This is an inescapable phenomenon for experimental measures.

More problematically, variable Œæ can display a systematic bias, meaning that E(Œæ) ‚â† 0. Since the bias is generally different for the ‚Äòtrue‚Äô and ‚Äòpredicted‚Äô versions, the comparison between the two (eq. 16) will be systematically flawed. To counteract this effect, we applied a number of correction procedures when computing indicators Z, q and V, to ensure that they are globally unbiased. We only provide an overview here, and refer to supporting S1 Text for a detailed description.

First, when the optimal vector a is computed with Fisher‚Äôs linear discriminant, it systematically underestimates the JND Z (overestimates the sensitivity Y). Essentially, vector ar computed through eq. 12 finds artificial ‚Äúholes‚Äù in matrix C ‚Äæ ‚Äæ r which are only due to its imprecise measurement‚Äîa phenomenon known as statistical overfitting. The less recording trials, the more overfitting there will be [40, 41]. We addressed this problem with a regularization technique, inspired by Bayesian linear regression [42]. We replaced eq. 12 by the following: a r = ( C ¬Ø ¬Ø r + Œª Id ) ‚àí 1 b ¬Ø r b ¬Ø r ‚ä§ ( C ¬Ø ¬Ø r + Œª Id ) ‚àí 1 b ¬Ø r , where the strength of parameter Œª imposes the degree of regularization. We chose Œª according to an ‚Äòempirical Bayes‚Äô principle, to maximize the likelihood of the data under a given statistical model (supporting S1 Text, section 4). It largely mitigated the effects of overfitting, without totally suppressing them‚Äîas can be seen in Fig. 5D-E.

Second, indicator V (eq. 15) can also display substantial biases (E(Œæ) ‚â† 0 in the above discussion). Indeed, its computation relies on squared quantities‚Äîsuch as d ‚Äæ i 2 or q ‚Äæ ‚Äæ 2‚Äîthat systematically transform measurement errors into positive biases. The required corrections are very similar to the classic ‚ÄúN/(N‚àí1)‚Äù correction for the naive variance estimator, with the additional difficulty that V is affected by two sources of noise: the finite number of recording trials, and the finite number of recorded neurons. The exact corrections to ensure an unbiased estimation of V are detailed in supporting S1 Text, section 5.

Third, indicator q(u, t) displays little or no measurement bias‚Äîbecause its computation is essentially linear. Yet, it can display an important level of measurement noise (Var(Œæ) ‚â´ 0 in the above discussion) that may deteriorate the subsequent inference procedure. We mitigated this measurement noise by applying a bi-temporal Gaussian smoothing to q‚ãÜ(u, t) and predictions q(u, t), with time constant 10 msec.

To estimate the measurement errors due to the finite number of trials, we produced 14 sets of surrogate data by sampling our original trials with replacement (bootstrap procedure). These resamplings were used to derive some of the correction terms for V, and also to derive confidence intervals on our final estimators, as shown in Fig. 6. This departure from the statistical canon was imposed by the length of the whole inference procedure (see supporting S1 Text, section 5, for details).

sec.title: Reproduction of our results and implementation
sec.p: In the Supporting Information, we provide a generic implementation of the inference method (‚ÄúCase 2‚Äù above) in MATLAB, which can be applied to any data from a 2AFC discrimination task. We also provide the Python code for the network simulation, and MATLAB scripts for the reproduction of the experimental Figures in this article (Fig. 4‚Äì7).
